widgets.content: Why every  organisation  should have an  Insider Theat  Program
In this module  you will:
Find out what the Insider  Threat is    Explore threat data    Discover the ROI of Insider  Threat Programs
It's not a matter of “if”.  It's a matter of “when”.
You try to log into your work computer. It seems the system is blocked. A vengeful IT team member, who was fired earlier, has blocked all IT systems.
What will most likely be your first thought?
Oh no! Not again.
I did not know we were that vulnerable to actions from one single employee.
This would not have happened if we had an effective Insider Threat Program in place.
Submit
This is not an imaginary scenario. The 'Insider Threat' is real.

Here is a surprising fact:    **In 2018, 99% of organisations will report feeling vulnerable to Insider Threat attacks.**    This means it is time to act. All organisations, and especially those that work within transportation and critical infrastructure, have to develop, implement and evaluate Insider Threat Progams.
A definition of the Insider Threat
Insider Threat
ɪnˈsaɪdəʳ θrɛt
Any individual with inside knowledge or access has the potential to harm the organisation and its people.
Click on the 4 must knows:
Insiders are not always employees

Have you thought of the following examples? They all have either inside knowledge or access to an organisation:  * Contractors * Subcontractors * Interns * Job students * Business partners * Vendors * Suppliers
The supply chain shows where assets are at risk

Organisational assets can also be present at the location of other organisations, or other organisations might have access to your organisation's assets or data.    Of course, this has to be taken into account when developing an Insider Threat Program.
Incidents happen daily but most cases remain undetected

Small incidents can have great effect. These Insider incidents often go unnoticed:   * No security program and/or policies.  * Lending ID cards to colleagues.  * Illegal copying of information to personal devices.  * Sharing passwords.  * Letting visitors in without ID cards.
Malicious Insiders act in different ways

* **Theft:** Espionage, data loss, property theft, or media leaks.  * **Sabotage:** The destruction of organisational equipment, compromise of operations, corruption of information, or disruption of the decision-making ability.  * **Workplace violence:** Intimidating co-workers, physical violence, stabbings, shootings. * **Terrorism support, infiltration, radicalisation:** Recruiting co-workers, using organisational assets to provide material support to terrorist organisations, or attempting to influence organisational policy or operations.
Security employee unmasks a colleague  and prevents an Insider attack     01:48
Threat data
Threat types
Insiders who want to harm an organisation are a serious threat. However, all organisations have to be aware of other types of Insider Threats as well.
Click on the items to explore the various types of Insider Threats.
Malicious
Negligent
Accidental
Malicious
Employees who aim to hurt the organisation or colleagues.
**Motivation**  * Personal advantage * Money * Plotical or religious belief
**Examples**  * Terrorism (support)  * Theft (of information)  * Violence or threat of violence  * Espionage  * Helping others obtain illegal access
Negligent
Employees who are aware of security policies and procedures but decide to bypass them.
**Motivation**  * Carelessness  * Helping co-workers  * Ignorance

**Examples**  * Lending security badges to co-workers.  * Taking home or sharing information.  * Lack of 'Bring Your Own Device(BYOD) policy/procedures.  * Unauthorised use of PEDs (Personal Electronic Device).
Accidental
Employees who are aware of security policies and procedures but accidentally bypass them.
**Examples**  * Leaving your computer unlocked.  * Leaving a door unlocked.  * Accidentally sharing information.
We are not prepared

More and more organisations are becoming aware of the Insider Threat. Data confirms that we are insufficently prepared. We are not equipped to deal with minor accidental threats, let alone major malicious and terrorist threats from the inside.

Concerns
You already know that 99% of organisations will feel vulnerable to Insider Threat attacks in 2018. But what types of Insider Threats are they concerned about?
**Source: '2018 Insider Threat REPORT' By Cybersecurity Insiders**
Attacks

Sometimes one Insider attack can have global impact. Perhaps you can remember the suicidal Germanwings co-pilot who willingly crashed his Airbus, killing 150 persons, including himself. This one incident has led to stricter policies concerning the mental health of flight deck crew.    However, the following statistics show the scale of the Insider Threat we are dealing with:   * In the US, there were 1.900+ reported incidents. About 9% of these incidents involved malicious Insiders.   * 53% of organisations confirmed Insider attacks against their organisation in the past 12 months.
Programs in place
Insider Threat Programs help counter the threat we are facing. But how many organisations have a program in place?
**Source: '2018 Insider Threat REPORT' By Cybersecurity Insiders**
The ROI of an Insider Threat Program
The costs of Insider incidents

Insider Threats are both costly and damaging.   In absence of European data, let us have a look at some FBI figures:   * The average cost of an Insider incident is €350.000.  * Average victim loss: ~€15M / year.  * Multiple incidents exceed €1 billion.
A well-built and implemented Insider Threat Program provides real and immediate Return on Investment (ROI).
Show me  the ROI
The Return On Investment

**Return on Investment possibilities**   * Increased client confidence.  * Reduced risk of compromise.  * Increased employee productivity.  * Increased investor confidence.  * Protection of brand and reputation.  * Create asset protection culture.  * Lower insurance premiums.  * Employees feeling safer.  * More efficient decision making.  * Early threat detection.  * Lower remediation cost(s).  * Reduced impact of compromise.  * Halt the loss of intellectual property.  * Halt the loss of sensitive commercial information.  * Bolster existing security measures.  * Reduced time to resolve incidents.
A surprising fact
Half of the employees who left or lost their jobs in the last 12 months kept confidential corporate data.    40% of them plan to use it at their new job!
Summary

Any individual with inside knowledge or access has the potential to harm the organisation and its people.    All organisations are vulnerable to Insider Threats.     A well-built and implemented Insider Threat Program provides real and immediate Return on Investment (ROI).
